elements.title: Strategic M&A and Customer Expansion Strategies

data.value: We believe we have a strong opportunity to address the security needs of resource constrained organizations of any size.
We see significant opportunity to deepen our relationship with our existing customers.
We intend to continue to drive customer satisfaction and renewals.
We continue to expand our strategic partnerships.
We continue to make investments to expand our international presence.
We have and may continue to make acquisitions that enhance the value of our Insight Platform.
We sell our solutions through direct and indirect channels.
A dedicated support team is essential for customer satisfaction.
We focus on increasing the strength of the Rapid7 brand and generating leads.
Our consolidation offerings are refining how our salesforce goes to market.
The integration of IntSights and any other acquisition poses challenges due to coordinating geographically separate organizations and integrating personnel with diverse business cultures and systems.
There is a need to implement or improve controls, procedures, and policies at acquired businesses that may have lacked effective systems prior to acquisition.
The acquisition and integration processes are complex, expensive, and time consuming, potentially interrupting product development, sales activities, and overall operations.
There is a risk of being unable to retain key personnel from an acquired company, which could undermine the anticipated benefits of the acquisition.
Limited due diligence may result in discovering that the acquired products or technologies are not as capable as initially thought.
Post-acquisition, unforeseen liabilities arising from past or present operations may exceed the negotiated warranty and indemnity limitations.
Failure to meet publicly announced guidance or analyst expectations could result in a decline in stock price.
Reliance on channel partners for sales introduces additional risk, particularly if partners prioritize competing products or are inefficient in marketing and selling the company’s offerings.
Stockholder actions must be effected at duly called annual or special meetings rather than by written consent.
An advance notice procedure is established for stockholder proposals, including nominations for director candidates.
Directors elected prior to the 2021 annual meeting serve three-year staggered terms; subsequent to the 2023 meeting, directors hold one-year terms.
Approval by holders of a majority of the voting power is required to adopt, amend, or repeal the bylaws or certificate of incorporation provisions regarding director election and removal.
Cumulative voting in the election of directors is prohibited.
Board vacancies may be filled only by a majority of directors then in office, even if less than a quorum.
The provisions may frustrate or prevent attempts by stockholders to replace or remove current management.
Note holders have the right to require repurchase if a fundamental change occurs before the notes' maturity date.
In certain make-whole fundamental changes, the conversion rate of the notes may be increased for holders electing conversion.
Indentures prohibit engaging in certain mergers or acquisitions unless the surviving entity assumes the obligations under the notes, potentially deterring favorable acquisition offers.
Under Delaware law, business combinations with an interested stockholder are restricted for three years following the acquisition of an interest.
The amended and restated certificate of incorporation designates the Delaware Court of Chancery as the exclusive forum for various types of litigation, which may limit stockholders' judicial options.

elements.title: Financial Disclosures: Goodwill Impairment, Foreign Currency & Derivative Activities and Stock-Based Compensation

data.value: An annual single-step goodwill impairment test was performed as of December 31, 2022. The fair value of the single reporting unit, based on market capitalization, exceeded its carrying amount and no impairment was recognized.

The functional currency for foreign subsidiaries is the U.S. dollar. Monetary assets and liabilities are translated at balance sheet date rates; nonmonetary items at historical rates. In 2022, foreign currency transaction losses were $1.4 million, while in 2021 transaction and re-measurement losses were $0.3 million and $1.7 million, respectively.

The company is exposed to currency exchange rate risk and manages this via foreign currency derivative contracts designated as cash flow hedges. As of December 31, 2022, outstanding forward contracts had a total notional value of $44.9 million (compared to $34.7 million in 2021), and all cash flow hedges were considered effective.

Stock-based compensation expense related to stock options, RSUs, PSUs, and ESPP purchase rights is calculated based on the estimated fair value using the Black-Scholes option pricing model on the grant date. The model uses assumptions including expected option life, stock volatility, risk-free rate, and expected dividends.

Active Metasploit community contributing to security research.
Attacker Intelligence and Internet Intelligence.
The National Exposure Index, The Industry Cyber Exposure Report, Under the Hoodie.
Velociraptor monitoring and digital forensic capabilities.
Built-in risk prioritization, IT-integrated remediation projects, tracking of goals and SLAs, and pre-built automation workflows designed to accelerate risk mitigation.
Dynamic application security testing and run-time application security monitoring to continuously analyze web applications for vulnerabilities throughout the software development life cycle.
Advanced external threat intelligence that proactively monitors clear, deep, and dark web sources to provide actionable, real-time information on threats and enable informed decision-making.
Allows connection of disparate cybersecurity, IT, and DevOps solutions to build automated workflows that eliminate repetitive and manual tasks, yielding measurable time and cost savings.

A cloud-native platform that collects and analyzes data, providing unified data collection, scalable delivery with high redundancy, endpoint detection, network traffic analysis, and overall support for comprehensive cybersecurity risk management.

Features include unified data collection across the IT environment, agentless and agent-based architectures, endpoint detection and visibility, and network traffic analysis to enhance investigation and threat response.

elements.title: Cloud and Virtual Infrastructure Assessment & Insight Platform Features

data.value: Integrates with cloud services and virtual infrastructure to ensure secure configuration as networks and systems continuously evolve.
Leverages Project Sonar to regularly scan the public internet, identifying global vulnerabilities and previously unknown, externally facing assets.
Incorporates extensive user and attacker behavior analytics (UBA and ABA) to detect compromised credentials, lateral movement, and malicious activities.
Offers built-in risk assessment, prioritization, and IT-integrated remediation workflows to help security teams focus on what is critical.
Provides integrated threat feeds, combining public and proprietary threat intelligence to highlight the most relevant risks.
Centralizes log management by correlating millions of events to users and assets, increasing visibility and compliance without heavy hardware.
Includes intruder traps such as honeypots, honey users, honey credentials, and honey files to detect attacker behavior early in the attack chain.
Facilitates automation with built-in, code-free workflows (e.g., assisted patching and automated containment) for streamlined security operations.
Offers a highly extensible platform with approximately 500 plugins for seamless integration of diverse security tools.
Delivers Insight Platform solutions as SaaS products globally, including offerings like InsightIDR, a unified XDR and SIEM solution.
InsightIDR, InsightCloudSec, InsightVM

Unifies SIEM, UEBA, EDR, NTA, and cloud detection to detect stealthy attacks; reduces signal-to-noise ratio; offers high-fidelity prioritized alerts; includes a correlation engine, powerful search, forensic capabilities, and prebuilt workflows to shorten investigation time (MTTR).
Offered through a cloud-based subscription with an option for Managed Detection and Response (MDR) service providing 24x7x365 monitoring and incident response.
Includes Enhanced Network Traffic Analysis for comprehensive network monitoring and Enhanced Endpoint Telemetry for detailed endpoint activity logging.

Cloud risk and compliance management platform integrating posture management, workload protection, infrastructure entitlements management, infrastructure-as-code security, and Kubernetes protection. Provides unified visibility across multi-cloud and container environments with automated remediation.

Vulnerability management solution offering continuous visibility, risk scoring based on integrated threat intelligence, and integrations with ServiceNow, IBM Bigfix, Microsoft SCCM, and Jira to streamline remediation efforts.
Helps security operations teams reduce investigation times, improve detection accuracy, and efficiently manage vulnerabilities and compliance risks.

Security practitioners faced significant challenges protecting organizations from threats due to a complex cybersecurity environment and budget constraints.
Delivered value via Rapid7’s Insight platform, enabling best-in-class security operations across traditional and cloud environments.
Introduced new core consolidation offerings: Cloud Risk Complete and Threat Complete, aimed at reducing vendor count and improving security outcomes.
Rapid7’s total ARR grew 19% year-over-year to $714 million at the end of 2022.
ARR per customer exceeded $65,000, marking a 12% growth year-over-year.
Expanded by over 300 basis points.
Delivered over $40 million in Free Cash Flow.
Focused on profitable growth, vendor consolidation, and closing the security achievement gap while targeting a 'Rule of 40' performance model.
Committed to adapting to market conditions and creating a more secure digital future for customers and stakeholders.
Rapid7 is on a mission to create a safer digital world by making cybersecurity simpler and more accessible.
Revenue increased from $244.1 million in 2018 to $685.1 million in 2022, representing a 29% compound annual growth rate.
In 2022, 2021, and 2020, recurring revenue accounted for 94%, 92%, and 90% of total revenue respectively.
Net losses were $124.7 million in 2022, $146.3 million in 2021, and $98.8 million in 2020.
As of December 31, 2022, more than 10,000 customers relied on Rapid7’s technology, services, and research.
Products include Incident Detection and Response (IDR), Cloud Security solutions, and Vulnerability Risk Management (VRM7).
The company has not been profitable historically and has posted net losses every year since inception.

elements.title: Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations

data.value: Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations

Rapid7 is on a mission to create a safer digital world by simplifying cybersecurity. The discussion highlights the challenges of managing modern attack surfaces and the increasing complexity due to cloud migration, distributed workforces, and connected devices.
The document contains forward-looking statements and refers readers to risk factors elsewhere in the report, emphasizing that actual results could differ materially.

Rapid7 offers comprehensive security solutions divided into six key areas: Incident Detection and Response, Cloud Security, Vulnerability Risk Management, Application Security, Threat Intelligence, and Security Orchestration and Automation Response. These are delivered via cloud-based subscriptions and managed services.
The company serves over 10,000 customers in 146 countries, with a diversified revenue stream where no single customer accounts for more than 1% of revenue.
The discussion emphasizes investment in technology simplification, research, and partnerships to address emerging cybersecurity risks and close the 'security achievement gap'.

elements.title: Financial Performance and Operating Metrics Overview

data.value: Licensed software is sold through term licenses bundled with maintenance, support, and content subscriptions for Nexpose, Metasploit, and AppSpider. Professional services such as deployment, training, incident response, penetration testing, and security advisory are also offered, either bundled or standalone on fixed fee or time-and-materials agreements.
Recurring revenue (from term licenses, content subscriptions, managed services, cloud subscriptions, maintenance and support) accounted for 94% of total revenue in 2022, 92% in 2021, and 90% in 2020.

Annualized Recurring Revenue (ARR): 714,231 (2022) vs 599,020 (2021) in thousands of dollars, with YoY growth of 19.2% (2022) compared to 38.4% (2021); Number of customers: 10,929 (2022) vs 10,283 (2021) with growth of 6.3% (2022) vs 18.0% (2021); ARR per customer: 65.4 (2022) vs 58.3 (2021) in thousands of dollars, with YoY growth of 12.2% (2022) vs 17.3% (2021).

The company monitors total revenue, non‐GAAP income from operations, and non‐GAAP operating margin to assess operational effectiveness, financial performance, and to aid in period-to-period and competitor comparisons. Free cash flow is defined as cash provided by operating activities less purchases of property and equipment and capitalization of internal-use software costs.

The company aims to drive continued revenue growth through increased sales of products and professional services to new and existing customers, with key metrics serving as supplemental information for financial decision-making.

elements.title: Non-GAAP Financial Results and Key Performance Metrics

data.value: Annualized Recurring Revenue (ARR) is defined as the annual value of all recurring revenue related to contracts in place at the end of the quarter. ARR is an operating metric and should be viewed independently of revenue and deferred revenue.
Customer is defined as any entity with an active Rapid7 recurring revenue contract as of the measurement date, excluding certain low-value contracts (< $2,400/year) for InsightOps and Logentries.
Defined as ARR divided by the number of customers at the end of the period.

Measures include non-GAAP gross profit, income from operations, operating margin, net income (loss), net income (loss) per share, adjusted EBITDA, and free cash flow. These are provided in a reconciliation to comparable GAAP measures.

Excludes items such as stock-based compensation expense, amortization of acquired intangible assets, amortization of debt discount and issuance costs, and induced conversion expense, among other non-recurring or non-cash items.

The non-GAAP metrics are used for financial and operational decision-making and as performance measures under the executive bonus plan, aiding investors in evaluating period-to-period comparisons and overall business success.

elements.title: Expense Adjustments in Adjusted EBITDA Calculation

data.value: Non-ordinary course litigation expenses (including legal costs and settlement fees) are excluded because they are not indicative of core operating performance. Ordinary legal expenses, such as those for maintaining and enforcing the intellectual property portfolio and license agreements, are not adjusted.

Expenses unrelated to current operations are excluded. For example, acquisition-related expenses for the year ended December 31, 2021 include $9.0 million of tax expense related to the sale of acquired intellectual property through an intercompany transaction from the Alcide acquisition.

data.key: Anti-dilutive impact of capped call transaction
data.value: Capped call transactions are used to offset potential dilution from conversion features in convertible senior notes. Their anti-dilutive impact is reflected in non-GAAP net income (loss) per diluted share.

Defined as net loss before interest income, interest expense, other income (expense), provision for income taxes, depreciation expense, amortization of intangible assets, stock‐based compensation expense, acquisition-related expenses, and litigation-related expenses.

elements.title: Operating Expenses and Financial Performance Breakdown

data.value: Includes research and development, sales and marketing, and general and administrative expenses. Overhead costs include depreciation, facilities, IT (personnel and infrastructure), information security, and recruiting, allocated based on headcount.

Comprises personnel costs (salaries, payroll-related costs, bonuses, stock-based compensation), third-party infrastructure costs, travel and entertainment, consulting and professional fees, and allocated overhead. Expected to increase in absolute dollars as investments in products and technology innovation grow, but decrease as a percentage of total revenue.

Encompasses personnel costs (salaries, payroll costs, commissions, bonuses, stock-based compensation), marketing activities, promotional events, travel and entertainment, training costs, amortization of deferred commissions and intangible assets, and allocated overhead. Expected to increase in absolute dollars as revenue growth investments continue, but decrease as a percentage of total revenue.

Consists of personnel costs for executive, legal, human resources, finance and accounting departments (including salaries, bonuses, stock-based compensation), along with travel, professional fees, litigation-related expenses, insurance, acquisition-related expenses, amortization of intangible assets, and allocated overhead. Expected to increase absolutely but remain relatively consistent as a percentage of total revenue.
Primarily derived from interest on cash and cash equivalents and investments.

Primarily includes contractual interest expense and amortization of debt issuance costs associated with convertible senior notes and revolving credit facilities, as well as induced conversion expense.
Primarily reflects unrealized and realized gains and losses due to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates.

Includes income taxes in foreign jurisdictions, withholding taxes, and state income taxes in the United States. A full valuation allowance is maintained for deferred tax assets due to historical losses and uncertainty of realization.

This table presents a consolidated statement of operations from 2020 to 2022. The company shows growing revenue (from $411.5M in 2020 to $685.1M in 2022) but continues to operate at a loss. Product revenue is the main source of income, while sales and marketing represents the largest operating expense. The net loss in 2022 was $124.7M, an improvement from $146.3M in 2021.
Cost of revenue and operating expenses include stock-based compensation expense and depreciation and amortization expense as detailed in subsequent tables.

The table shows stock-based compensation expenses across different business functions from 2020 to 2022. Total compensation has increased significantly from $63.9M in 2020 to $119.9M in 2022. Research and development consistently represents the largest expense category, accounting for about 42% of total compensation in 2022. All categories show an upward trend over the three-year period, with the most substantial growth in absolute terms occurring in R&D spending.

Cost of revenue: 2022=26520, 2021=21484, 2020=13218; Research and development: 2022=4133, 2021=3566, 2020=2844; Sales and marketing: 2022=7742, 2021=6277, 2020=4779; General and administrative: 2022=2643, 2021=2174, 2020=1790; Total depreciation and amortization expense: 2022=41038, 2021=33501, 2020=22631

The table shows depreciation and amortization expenses across different business categories from 2020 to 2022. Total expenses have increased consistently year over year, from $22.6M in 2020 to $33.5M in 2021, and $41.0M in 2022. Cost of revenue represents the largest component, accounting for approximately 65% of total depreciation and amortization expense across all years. All categories show an upward trend, with the most significant growth observed between 2020 and 2022.

This table presents a consolidated statement of operations showing key financial metrics from 2020 to 2022. Product revenue consistently represents over 93% of total revenue (from 93.1% in 2020 to 94.5% in 2022). Operating losses improved from -22.4% in 2021 to -16.3% in 2022. The company shows significant investment in sales & marketing (44.9% in 2022) and research & development (27.7% in 2022), with an overall improvement in loss before income taxes from -25.4% in 2021 to -17.8% in 2022.

This table provides a breakdown of revenue by category comparing 2022 and 2021. Total revenue increased by 28% (an increase of $149.7 million) from $535,404,000 in 2021 to $685,083,000 in 2022. Products revenue grew by 29.3% while Professional services revenue increased by 8.6%. The total increase comprises $133.9 million of organic growth — including $12.7 million from new customers and $121.2 million from existing customers (renewals, upsells, and cross-sells) — and an additional $15.8 million related to the acquisition of IntSights in July 2021. Revenue was generated from $108.7 million in North America and $41.0 million from the rest of the world.
2022: 68.7%, 2021: 68.4% (slightly increased)

Total cost of revenue increased by $45.4M, driven by a $18.2M increase in personnel costs (including $3.9M stock-based compensation and $1.5M related to IntSights acquisition), a $14.8M increase in cloud computing costs, $5.9M increase in allocated overhead, $3.1M increase in amortization of acquired intangibles, $1.6M increase in amortization for in-house software, and $1.8M increase in other expenses.

Increase driven by $18.5M in personnel costs (including $15.2M in salaries plus $3.3M stock-based compensation), $8.1M higher allocated overhead mainly from IT and facilities costs, and $2.6M increase in other expenses.

Increase comprised of $30.4M in personnel costs (with $23.0M increase in salaries, including $5.2M related to IntSights acquisition and $7.4M in stock-based compensation), $10.6M higher commission expense, $10.0M increase in allocated overhead (IT and facilities), $3.2M increase in marketing/advertising, $1.2M rise in amortization of acquired intangibles, $2.5M increase in travel and entertainment, and $2.1M in other expenses.

elements.title: Cash Flow Analysis – Operating, Investing, and Financing Activities

data.value: Net operating assets and liabilities changes driven by a $24.4M increase in accounts receivable, $13.4M increase in deferred contract acquisition and fulfillment costs, $8.9M increase in prepaid expenses and other assets, a $2.4M decrease in accounts payable, and a $0.4M decrease in other liabilities. These were partially offset by a $37.4M increase in deferred revenue and an $8.6M increase in accrued expenses, all affecting operating cash flow.

Used $40.0M of cash, including $20.4M in capital expenditures for computer equipment and leasehold improvements, $17.1M for capitalization of internal-use software costs, $1.5M in net investment purchases, and $1.0M in other investments.

Used $325.4M of cash; major components include $358.4M for acquisitions (IntSights, Alcide, Velocidex) net of cash acquired, $9.9M for internal-use software costs, $9.0M in capital expenditures, and $3.0M for other investing activities, partially offset by $54.9M from investment sales and maturities.

Used $156.3M of cash, with $125.8M paid for the acquisition of DivvyCloud (net of $5.0M cash acquired), $13.8M in capital expenditures, $10.6M for net investment purchases, and $6.1M for internal-use software capitalization.
Provided $7.4M of cash primarily from $11.9M proceeds under the ESPP and $3.3M from stock option exercises, offset by $7.5M in withholding taxes and $0.3M in acquisition-related payments.

Provided $264.1M of cash, mainly from $585.0M in proceeds from issuance of the 2027 Notes (net of $15.0M issuance costs), $9.3M from ESPP common stock issuance, and $4.3M from stock option exercises, partially offset by significant redemptions, repurchases, payments for capped calls, withholding taxes, and acquisition-related costs.

Provided $200.9M of cash, largely from $222.8M from issuance of the 2025 Notes (net of $7.2M issuance costs), $7.8M from stock option exercises, and $7.1M from ESPP common stock issuance, offset by payments for capped calls, withholding taxes, debt issuance costs, and deferred consideration.
No relationships with unconsolidated entities or off-balance sheet financing arrangements; not engaged in trading non-exchange traded contracts.

elements.title: Critical Accounting Estimates and Revenue Recognition

data.value: Our consolidated financial statements are prepared under GAAP and require making estimates and assumptions affecting assets, liabilities, revenue, expenses, and disclosures. These estimates are based on historical experience and other factors.

Revenue is generated from cloud-based subscriptions, managed services, term software licenses, content subscriptions, maintenance and support, and professional services. Contracts include multiple performance obligations which are accounted for separately using a relative standalone selling price (SSP) methodology.

Contract costs, primarily sales commissions, are deferred and amortized on a systematic basis over an estimated benefit period, typically five years for new customer contracts, with adjustments for renewals and professional services.

Refer to Note 2, Summary of Significant Accounting Policies in the Annual Report on Form 10-K for details on recent pronouncements and their expected impact on results of operations and financial conditions.

The fair value of awards (PSUs) is recognized as expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period, generally the vesting period. The actual number of PSUs earned is determined based on performance conditions, with reassessments each reporting period and adjustments made based on probability of vesting. Forfeitures are recognized when they occur.
Advertising costs are expensed as incurred and recorded in sales and marketing expense. The expenses incurred were $22.7 million in 2022, $21.3 million in 2021, and $16.4 million in 2020.

Income taxes are accounted for using the asset and liability method. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for temporary differences, with valuation allowances applied if it is more likely than not that some or all deferred tax assets will not be realized. Adjustments to the valuation allowance affect the provision for income taxes.

Basic net loss per share is calculated by dividing net loss by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding. Diluted net loss per share considers all potentially dilutive securities, including stock options, RSUs, PSUs, ESPP impacts, shares from acquisitions, and convertible senior notes.

The FASB issued ASU 2021-08 regarding the accounting for contract assets and liabilities acquired in business combinations. This standard is effective for periods beginning after December 15, 2022, with early adoption permitted, and was adopted early on January 1, 2022. It will be applied prospectively to business combinations on or after that date.

The table compares two sets of convertible notes: the 2025 Notes and the 2027 Notes. The 2025 Notes have a higher interest rate (2.25%) and effective interest rate (2.88%), mature on May 1, 2025, have an initial conversion price of $61.02, and represent 3.8 million shares. The 2027 Notes have a lower interest rate (0.25%) and effective interest rate (0.67%), mature on March 15, 2027, have an initial conversion price of $103.38, and represent 58 million shares. Both series follow a semi-annual interest payment schedule.

Key attributes for each note include note type, maturity date, interest rate, first interest payment date, effective interest rate, interest payment dates, rate per $1,000 principal, initial conversion price, and number of shares.

The conversion terms allow holders to convert their notes under specific conditions during designated calendar quarters, measurement periods, or upon redemption events. Conversion can be exercised at any time on or after November 1, 2024 for the 2025 Notes and December 15, 2026 for the 2027 Notes, subject to criteria such as common stock sale price thresholds, redemption notices, and specified corporate events including fundamental changes.

For accounting purposes, the principal less debt issuance costs of the Notes is recorded as debt on the consolidated balance sheet. Debt issuance costs are amortized to interest expense using the effective interest method over the contractual term of the Notes.

elements.title: Convertible Notes Repurchase and Induced Conversion Expenses

data.value: During the first quarter of 2021, a portion of the proceeds from the 2027 Notes issuance and 2.2 million common shares were used to repurchase and retire $182.6 million aggregate principal of the convertible 2023 Notes, including payment of accrued and unpaid interest.
Additional common stock valued at $2.7 million was issued as an inducement, recorded as part of interest expense under ASC 470-20.
In Q1 2021, holders converted $2.0 million principal of 2023 Notes; in Q4 2021 the remaining $45.4 million principal was redeemed partly with cash and partly with common stock.

Privately negotiated capped calls were entered into for the 2023, 2025, and 2027 Notes to reduce potential dilution and offset excess cash payments, subject to adjustments for specified extraordinary and disruption events.

This section of the Annual Report on Form 10-K includes forward-looking statements that highlight risks, uncertainties, and assumptions which could result in materially different future results from those presently expressed or implied.
anticipate, believe, can, continue, could, estimate, expect, intend, may, plan, project, seek, should, target, will, would

Risks related to customer acquisition and retention, economic volatility, software spending fluctuations, inflation, increased interest rates, competition, technological change, growth management, revenue diversification, potential acquisitions, capital expenditures, and future stock performance.
Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934
Forward-looking statements are only valid as of the report date, and the company assumes no obligation to update them in the future.
Quarterly operating results may vary from period to period, potentially causing the stock trading price to decline.
Significant growth experienced; inadequate management of future growth and scaling infrastructure may adversely affect operations.
Prolonged economic uncertainties or downturns could adversely affect the business and its financial condition.
Failures, errors, or defects in solutions may harm the brand and reputation, affecting customer confidence and operating results.
Business and growth depend substantially on customer renewals and expansion of subscription offerings.
Potential security breaches or unauthorized access to customer data could harm reputation and incur liabilities.
Intense competition in the market could adversely affect business, financial condition, and results of operations.
Inability to hire, train, and retain qualified personnel may negatively impact the business.
Pursuit of international expansion adds operational complexity and may affect overall performance if not managed well.
Domestic and international privacy and cybersecurity concerns related to data collection and storage could have a material adverse effect.
Failure to successfully implement products or maintain high-quality customer support may impair customer perceptions and damage the brand.
Not meeting publicly announced guidance or expectations could lead to a decline in the stock price.
Reliance on third-party software and data may expose the business to risks if these components fail or are difficult to replace.
Assertions of infringement or other intellectual property issues by third parties could result in significant costs and harm operations.
Perceived vulnerability of cloud-based solutions might deter organizations from purchasing the company’s offerings.
Significant debt levels may decrease business flexibility, increase borrowing costs, and affect the ability to secure additional capital.
Operations and financial results are subject to various risks and uncertainties which may affect business performance.

Operating results may vary; potential risks include demand for products, customer renewal rates, competitive landscape, IT/security issues, operational costs, price competition, integration of acquired businesses, international expansion, and regulatory changes.
Material adverse effects on business, financial condition, and results of operations, possibly leading to decline in stock price.

elements.title: Risk Factors and Growth Management Challenges

data.value: Dependence on the strength of regional, national, and global economies may cause operational variability.
Impacts of climate change, natural disasters, terrorism, or war (e.g., Russia-Ukraine war) could lead to unpredictable results.
Future accounting pronouncements or changes in accounting policies/practices may affect operating results.
Fluctuations in operating results could lead to stock price declines, lawsuits including securities class action suits, and financial penalties if expectations are not met.
Rapid historical growth with increased revenue and headcount requires effective management of infrastructure, systems, and processes to avoid service outages and maintain quality.
Significant financial and operational investments will be necessary to support ongoing product evolution, customer expansion, and operational scalability.

elements.title: Risk Factors and Market Acceptance Challenges

data.value: Discussion of macroeconomic events impacting various risk factors including customer renewal rates, subscription offerings, and market acceptance.
Factors mentioned include global economic slowdown, inflation, foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations, geopolitical events (e.g., Russia-Ukraine war), and impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic.
Emphasis on the importance of customer renewals and expanding subscriptions for operating results and growth prospects.

Concerns regarding insufficient market acceptance of new and enhanced product offerings (e.g., Insight Platform, Cloud Security, Threat Intelligence) and challenges with consolidated platform sales approach.

elements.title: Risk Factors – Market Competition and Customer Acceptance

data.value: The company faces challenges in scaling operations and performing adequately to meet customer demands.
Customers are experiencing poor business conditions, leading to delays in IT purchases, partly as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.
There is a noted reluctance among customers to purchase cloud-based offerings.
If new or enhanced offerings do not achieve adequate acceptance in the market, the competitive position and revenue could be negatively impacted.

The market is highly competitive with numerous established and emerging competitors across various segments such as XDR, SIEM, Cloud Security, and more, which may lead to pricing pressures and reduced market share.
Increased competition could result in price reductions, fewer orders, reduced renewals, and ultimately negative impacts on gross margins and financial performance.
The document outlines challenges in attracting, motivating, and retaining qualified employees in tight labor markets, with potential adverse impacts on product development and service delivery.
There is concern that as the company grows, its corporate culture may be diluted, negatively affecting the ability to attract and retain top talent.
The sales cycle is described as being long and unpredictable, especially with large enterprises, leading to potential losses in revenue opportunities and increased operational expenses.
A significant portion of revenue is derived from vulnerability management products. Any decline in demand, failure to innovate, or price reductions in these offerings could harm operating results.
For years ended Dec 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, operations outside North America generated 21%, 19% and 17% of revenue respectively.
The growth strategy relies on continued international expansion, particularly in Europe and Asia.

Increased management, infrastructure and legal costs; reliance on channel partners; trade and foreign exchange restrictions; economic or political instability; difficulties in enforcing contracts and collecting receivables; regulatory changes (e.g., data privacy, protection and security); staffing and management challenges in foreign markets; intellectual property protection issues; high compliance costs with both foreign and U.S. laws; potential for unfair or corrupt business practices; and longer payment cycles.
Risks include political unrest, acts of terrorism, hostilities or war (notably mentioned are the Russian military actions in Ukraine), sanctions, embargoes, and adverse macroeconomic shifts.

Operations face risks from multiple and possibly overlapping regulations including U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, import/export laws, tariffs, trade barriers, and evolving foreign governmental regulations.
The Russia-Ukraine war and related sanctions, export controls, or other restrictive actions may materially impact future operations.
Deferred revenue recognition may delay the reflection of downturns or upturns in sales, affecting period results and future revenue.
Challenges in deploying products across diverse and complex IT environments, and issues in customer support, could impair reputation and affect renewals.
Difficulties in integrating acquired businesses, products, or technologies may negatively affect financial results and competitive positioning.

elements.title: Risks Related to Brand, Key Personnel, and Third-Party Dependencies

data.value: Failure to maintain and enhance the brand identity may adversely affect customer relationships, channel partnerships, and overall business revenues.
Reliance on senior management and key employees, including CEO Corey Thomas, represents a risk if they depart or are terminated, potentially delaying strategic objectives.

Dependence on third-party software and data providers may lead to increased operational costs and disruptions if these services experience errors, outages, or become unavailable on commercially reasonable terms.
Substantial expenditures required for brand promotion in a competitive market may not be offset by corresponding increases in revenue.

elements.title: Regulatory, Compliance and Partnership Risk Factors

data.value: Investments in technology alliances may grant competitors insight into our offerings, potentially reducing our competitive edge.
Failure of products to help customers comply with regulations (e.g., PCI, HIPAA, HITECH) could harm revenue and operating results.
Selling to government entities is challenging due to competitive bidding, budgetary cycles and the need for strict compliance with certifications.
Delayed product compliance with evolving legal, regulatory and industry standards may lead customers to switch to competitors or initiate legal actions.
Fluctuations in currency exchange rates, especially since revenue is mostly in U.S. dollars, could negatively affect financial results.
Non-compliance with requirements imposed by government or contractual obligations may expose the company to liability and reputational harm.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Foreign Currency Exposure and Intellectual Property

data.value: The document describes risks arising from operating in foreign currencies, primarily British pound sterling and euro, and notes that fluctuations in exchange rates can adversely affect business, operating results, financial condition and cash flows.
For the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, 10%, 10% and 9% of revenue was generated in foreign currencies respectively.

The company enters into forward contracts and uses options and foreign exchange swaps as hedging strategies to mitigate exposure to foreign currency fluctuations, although these may not completely eliminate the risk.

The document discusses the risks related to protecting proprietary technology and intellectual property, including reliance on patents, trademarks, copyrights, trade secret laws and contractual protections, which may not always provide sufficient protection or competitive advantage.

There is a risk of substantial costs and diversion of resources arising from disputes over intellectual property, including potential litigation, challenges to patent validity, and enforcement difficulties, particularly in foreign jurisdictions.

elements.title: Regulatory, Export Control, and Tax-Related Risk Factors

data.value: Open source projects have known security and architectural vulnerabilities that could adversely affect the business.
Products are subject to U.S. export and import laws and regulations, including export administration regulations and trade sanctions. Non-compliance could result in significant penalties.
In response to geopolitical events, such as the Russia-Ukraine war, stricter sanctions and export controls may disrupt international commerce and impair the ability to sell products globally.
Encryption technology in products requires proper export authorizations and compliance with import regulations, potentially delaying market entry.
Limitations on the use of net operating losses (NOLs) due to ownership changes may lead to higher future tax liabilities if these limitations materialize.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Tax Uncertainties and Cybersecurity

data.value: The text discusses subsidiaries reporting taxable income across various jurisdictions, intercompany relationships subject to complex transfer pricing regulations, and uncertainties in tax determinations that may lead to adverse effects from changes in tax laws and auditing outcomes.

Significant judgment is required in evaluating global tax positions and provisions, with potential discrepancies in income attribution between jurisdictions, which might result in material adverse effects on operations if final tax determinations differ from estimates.

The document highlights risks in data privacy and cybersecurity, including failures to detect vulnerabilities, potential false positives impacting the reliability of solutions, a dynamic threat landscape, and the possibility of security breaches that could harm reputation and customer confidence.

External elements such as foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations, conflicts (e.g., Ukraine-Russia conflict), and evolving cybersecurity threats as informed by governmental warnings are also mentioned as risk factors affecting both tax obligations and cybersecurity performance.

elements.title: Risk Factors and Disruptions in Infrastructure and Cybersecurity

data.value: The company relies on third-party data centers and cloud providers (e.g., Amazon Web Services) for computing and storage capacity, making its products and network infrastructure vulnerable to disruptions in these systems.

Disruptions, outages, and performance issues may arise from infrastructure changes, human or software errors, capacity constraints, and security attacks, potentially impacting service quality and customer satisfaction.

The risk of cyber attacks, including malware, ransomware, phishing, and supply-chain attacks, can jeopardize network security and the reliability of cloud-based products, increasing potential liability and reputational harm.

Interruptions or delays in service delivery may result in lost revenue, customer credits, non-renewals, and significant remediation costs, all of which could negatively affect the company's business operations and financial condition.
Integration of software code, such as the log4j vulnerability identified in late 2021, could be incorporated into our systems, posing significant security risks.
Breaches in our systems or those of third-party service providers due to employee error, misconduct, or external attacks may expose critical information.
Failure of internal or third-party security measures could lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and potential financial losses.
The increasing sophistication of state-sponsored cyber activity and the misuse of tools like Metasploit highlight the evolving nature of cyber threats.
Inadequate insurance coverage and potential legal liabilities, including regulatory enforcement and litigation, could adversely impact our financial condition.
Security breaches or perceived failures in our cybersecurity measures could harm customer confidence and damage our brand.

elements.title: Data Privacy and Cybersecurity Compliance Risks

data.value: Potential for government investigations, fines, penalties, audits and inspections due to non-compliance with data privacy and cybersecurity laws.
Exposure to class-related claims and other litigation, which could result in significant legal consequences and adverse publicity.
Compliance burdens imposed by laws such as the GDPR, UK GDPR, and various U.S. state laws, including potential fines up to 20 million euros or 4% of annual global turnover.
Risks associated with transferring personal data from Europe to non-European countries, relying on mechanisms like Standard Contractual Clauses which may be subject to legal uncertainty.
Increased costs and resource expenditures to comply with expanded legislation, mandatory disclosures, and other reporting requirements.

elements.title: Risks Related to Cybersecurity, Regulation, and Market Volatility

data.value: Cybersecurity concerns, whether valid or not, may inhibit market adoption of products, particularly in certain industries and foreign countries.
Active legislative discussions regarding laws or regulations may restrict the manner in which security research is conducted, including penetration testing and use of exploits.
Failure to comply with existing or changing laws, rules, or regulations could result in additional costs and force changes to business practices.
Organizations may be reluctant to purchase cloud-based offerings due to concerns over the vulnerability and security of the technology delivery model.
The common stock exhibits significant price volatility influenced by various factors including financial performance fluctuations, market conditions, regulatory changes, and potential litigation.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Market Performance, Dividend Policy, and Indebtedness

data.value: Negative or lack of analyst research and reports can lead to a decline in the trading price and volume of our common stock. Analyst downgrades or cessation of coverage may reduce market visibility.
The company does not intend to pay cash dividends in the foreseeable future, indicating that returns rely solely on stock price appreciation.

Future issuance of additional common stock or equity-linked securities, including through options or conversion of notes, may lower the market price of the common stock and adversely impact the trading price of the Notes.

A significant amount of debt, including outstanding notes and potential additional borrowing, could constrain cash flow and flexibility, impacting operations and increasing vulnerability to adverse economic conditions.
Our exposure will increase if the market price or the volatility of our common stock increases.
Conversion of the Notes will dilute the ownership interest of existing stockholders and may depress the price of our common stock.
The Notes, as described, are subject to conversion that could lead to dilution and adverse market effects, including short selling.
Failure to comply with governmental laws and regulations, including potential sanctions and enforcement actions, could materially harm our business.
Risks include natural disasters, climate change impacts, public health crises, and interruptions from various catastrophic events that may adversely affect operations.

elements.title: Risk Factors: Internal Controls & Financial Reporting

data.value: Obligation to maintain proper and effective internal controls over financial reporting as required under Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, with disclosure of material weaknesses.
Annual management report on internal control effectiveness, including independent auditor evaluation and potential adverse opinions if controls are found deficient.
Failures in internal controls could lead to restatements of financial statements, loss of investor confidence, and a decline in the value of common stock.
Risks associated with changes in accounting standards and potential need for additional capital which might affect financial performance and operational flexibility.
Existing anti-takeover measures may complicate changes in control and limit market actions against the current management.

elements.title: Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk

data.value: The disclosure details that operations and cash flows are subject to fluctuations due to changes in foreign currency exchange rates. A majority of customer contracts are denominated in U.S. dollars while expenses are in local currencies. The company uses forward contracts as cash flow hedges, although the effectiveness and availability of such hedges may be limited.

The text explains that cash, cash equivalents, and investments are subject to market risk from interest rate changes, which can affect interest income and the fair value of investments. Convertible senior notes' fair values are impacted by interest rate fluctuations, market conditions, and the conversion feature, though the fixed debt obligation minimizes impact on financial position.

It is stated that inflation has not materially affected the business in the last three years, but if significant inflationary pressures occur, the company may not be able to fully offset increased costs through price adjustments, which could harm business and financial results.

elements.title: Credit Risk, Deferred Contract Costs, and Asset Depreciation Disclosures

data.value: Accounts receivable deemed uncollectible are charged against the allowance for credit losses. The company monitors concentrations of credit risk across cash, receivables, investments, and derivatives, and mitigates risk by dealing predominantly with high-quality financial institutions.

Contract acquisition costs, mainly sales commissions, are deferred and amortized systematically over the estimated customer benefit period (typically five years for new customers, with adjustments for renewals), with related expense recorded in sales and marketing. Costs for professional services are expensed as incurred.

Property and equipment are recorded at cost and depreciated using the straight-line method. The depreciation schedule specifies: Computer equipment and software over 3 years; Furniture and fixtures over 3-5 years; Leasehold improvements over either the asset's useful life or the lease term, whichever is applicable.

Software development costs related to products for sale are expensed as incurred until technological feasibility is established. Due to the insignificant time between technological feasibility and product release, these costs have not been capitalized.
Controls can be circumvented by individual acts, collusion, or management override.
The system is based on assumptions about future events and may not achieve its goals under all conditions.
Inherent limitations in a cost-effective control system may lead to misstatements due to error or fraud.
No changes in internal control over financial reporting were identified as material or likely to be material under applicable rules.
None
Not Applicable

elements.title: Sales and Marketing Expenses Comparison December 31, 2021 vs 2020
Nature of the Business and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies

data.value: Rapid7, Inc. and subsidiaries are advancing security with visibility, analytics, and automation delivered through the Insight Platform.
Revenue is generated primarily from subscriptions and professional services. Revenue is recognized when a customer obtains control of promised products or services.
Consolidated financial statements are prepared in accordance with GAAP.
Management makes estimates affecting amounts in consolidated financial statements, including revenue transactions with multiple performance obligations.

elements.title: Revenue Recognition and Transaction Price Determination

data.value: The transaction price is based on the consideration expected for transferring products or services.
Included if no significant future reversal of cumulative revenue will occur.
Revenue recognized at the time products/services are transferred.
Generated primarily from sales of cloud subscriptions, recognized over time.
Fees generated from operations on behalf of customers, recognized over time.
Recognized over the contractual term for dependent licenses, distinct for non-dependent.

elements.title: Fair Value Hierarchy of Financial Assets and Liabilities

data.value: Subject to various federal, state and international laws and regulations affecting business.
Regulations relating to the privacy and security of customer and employee personal information.
Laws related to the export and import of products to certain countries or entities.
Anticipated laws that could limit or change data handling practices.
Increased compliance costs due to changing regulations.
Involved in legal proceedings with Finjan, Inc. in the United States District Court, District of Delaware, related to allegations of patent infringement.

Claims of infringement, misappropriation, and other violations of intellectual property rights are asserted, potentially against the company, its subsidiary (Rapid7 LLC), customers, and channel partners.

Exposure to substantial costs including damages, required cessation of certain business activities, increased development resources to redesign solutions, and possibly unfavorable royalty or licensing agreements.
Competitors have larger patent portfolios, increasing the risk of litigation, and the use of open source software introduces additional compliance and disclosure risks.
Litigation and related disputes may distract management and harm the company’s business, financial condition, and operational results.
Our current facilities are deemed adequate; however, we plan to add new facilities or expand existing ones to accommodate additional employees, with expected availability of suitable space as needed.

In October 2018, Finjan, Inc. initiated a lawsuit against us and our wholly-owned subsidiary, Rapid7 LLC, alleging patent infringement of seven patents. Finjan sought unspecified damages, attorneys' fees, and injunctive relief. We plan to vigorously contest these claims, and while the final outcome is uncertain, litigation may have an adverse impact due to defense and settlement costs, diversion of management resources, and related factors.

elements.title: Non-cancellable Purchase Commitments and Litigation Overview

data.value: Future non-cancellable purchase commitments as of December 31, 2022 (in thousands): 2023: 113953, 2024: 131538, 2025: 39107, 2026: 6265, 2027 and thereafter: 3613, Total: 294476. The table represents a financial obligation schedule with a declining trend over the period.
Limited product warranties are provided; historically, associated payments have been immaterial.

In October 2018, Finjan, Inc. filed a complaint alleging patent infringement of seven patents. The complaint seeks unspecified damages, attorneys' fees and injunctive relief. The company intends to contest the claims, though litigation may adversely impact financials through defense and settlement costs.

Standard indemnification provisions apply, including indemnification for losses related to intellectual property infringement claims and obligations that are generally perpetual. No costs have been incurred to defend such claims to date.
A discretionary 401(k) plan is in place for full-time U.S. employees with matching contributions made at management’s discretion (e.g., $4.3M in 2022).
The company operates in one segment with the CEO as the chief operating decision maker overseeing performance and resource allocation on a consolidated basis.

data.key: Investment in resources for cybersecurity training and certifications
data.value: Zero cost for product training materials and certification exams which contribute to lifelong learning.
Aim to increase representation of under-represented groups to 50% women and people of color in the U.S. employee base.
End of 2022: 14% of U.S. employees are from under-represented communities, and 33% identify as women.
Mandatory Global Diversity, Equity and Inclusion e-learning implemented.
Partnerships with STEM and inclusion programs to promote technology education.
Founded to promote diversity in cybersecurity workforce with investments totaling $2.5 million.
Multi-year partnership with USF to create the Rapid7 Cyber Threat Intelligence Lab.
